channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: One Day With an Ambulance in Britain: Long Waits, Rising Frustration
item.description: Britain is experiencing a crisis in ambulance response times, part of a broader breakdown in the country’s revered National Health Service. We rode with one crew to witness the problems in real time.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ann Taylor, 79, waited three hours for an ambulance and an additional two hours before she was allowed inside a hospital.

item.title: German Court Sentences Ex-Concentration Camp Secretary to Probation
item.description: Irmgard Furchner, who was in her late teens when she worked in the Stutthof camp, was convicted as the authorities make a final effort to seek justice for Nazi-era crimes.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Irmgard Furchner had asked to be tried in absentia, but the judge in Itzehoe, in northern Germany, ordered her to appear.

item.title: As Putin Admits Difficulties in Occupied Ukrainian Areas, Zelensky Visits Frontline City
item.description: On a day when the Russian president called on his security agencies to intensify their efforts in eastern and southern Ukraine, the Ukrainian leader visited Bakhmut, which Moscow has failed to capture.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: On the front line in the Lyman region of Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: Ukraine Urges Russian Soldiers to Surrender to Drones
item.description: Capitalizing on reports of low Russian morale, Ukraine has begun offering enemy troops detailed instructions on how to make their way over the battlefield and lay down their arms.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier operating a drone near the Kherson front in September.

item.title: China’s Abrupt Covid Pivot Leaves Many Without Medicines
item.description: Millions are desperate to get their hands on fever-reducing drugs and antivirals such as Pfizer’s Paxlovid as infections across China outpace supplies.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Isabelle Qian, Olivia Wang and Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Buying medicine at a pharmacy in Beijing on Tuesday. Medication has flown off drugstore shelves across China as signs of outbreaks of Covid have emerged.

item.title: As Tunisia Drifts Farther From Democracy, Voters Shun Election
item.description: Turnout in Saturday’s parliamentary elections was just over 11 percent, reflecting deep skepticism that politics can solve the North African nation’s grave governmental and economic crises.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Ahmed Ellali
item.media:description: Tunisia’s electoral board president, Farouk Bouasker, announcing the preliminary results of the parliamentary elections on Monday in the capital, Tunis. Just over 11 percent of eligible voters cast ballots.

item.title: In Fiji’s Election, One Former Coup Leader Displaces Another
item.description: The return of Sitiveni Rabuka paves the way for a potential pivot in a country where the United States and China are fighting for influence.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Sitiveni Rabuka, center, leaving a meeting in Suva, the capital of Fiji, on Tuesday. He is in line to take over as the country’s leader for the first time since 1999.

item.title: Boat With at Least 160 Rohingya Refugees Is Stranded at Sea
item.description: The U.N. called on countries in South Asia to rescue those on the vessel, who have been without food for weeks after leaving Bangladesh.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Karan Deep Singh
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: In November, another group of Rohingya refugees landed in a wooden boat in North Aceh, Indonesia.

item.title: From Zero Covid to No Plan: Behind China’s Pandemic U-Turn
item.description: After micromanaging the coronavirus strategy for nearly three years, the country’s leader, Xi Jinping, has suddenly left the populace to improvise.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Alexandra Stevenson and Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Covid testing booth in Shanghai on Wednesday.

item.title: As Peru’s Unrest Chases Away Visitors, Many Fear for Their Livelihood
item.description: In Cusco, the gateway to Machu Picchu and other ancient sites, tourist operators and hotel owners fear what the loss of visitors means for their livelihood.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj, Genevieve Glatsky and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: Workers on Saturday were trying to clear a large boulder placed by protesters to block the railway track that carries tourists to and from Machu Picchu.

item.title: South Africa’s President, Cyril Ramaphosa, Wins Battle to Lead A.N.C.
item.description: Despite a high-profile scandal, Cyril Ramaphosa consolidated support from the party that has dominated South Africa since independence. But with misery rising, can the A.N.C. retain its hold?
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, center, celebrating after the vote announcement on Monday.

item.title: Menorah That Symbolized Defiance Returns to Germany for Hanukkah
item.description: A 1931 photograph of a menorah on a windowsill also showed a Nazi flag in the street outside. This Hanukkah the menorah returned to Germany.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon

item.title: Mark Rutte Apologizes for Netherlands’ Role in Slave Trade
item.description: People were “exploited and abused in the name of the Dutch state,” Mark Rutte said, but some descendants of enslaved people say the government did not involve them in the apology.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Rutte of the Netherlands, at the National Archives in The Hague on Monday, apologized on behalf of his government for the country’s role in the slave trade.

item.title: King Charles III Is the New Face of U.K. Money
item.description: Pound notes with the new sovereign’s image will begin appearing in 2024, though money with his mother’s likeness will still be in circulation.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: The new bank notes from the Bank of England showing King Charles III.

item.title: UK Nurses, Emergency Responders and Rail Workers Walk Out
item.description: Continuing strikes over pay and economic conditions are likely to disrupt travel and services during the holiday season. Here’s what to expect.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: National Health Service nurses went on strike Tuesday. The union that represents them is seeking a 19 percent pay increase.

item.title: EPA Tightens Rules on Pollution From Vans, Buses and Trucks
item.description: For the first time in decades, the agency has restricted nitrogen dioxide emissions from heavy vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: The rule will require heavy-duty trucks to reduce emissions of nitrogen dioxide 48 percent by 2045.

item.title: 1922: Last War Prisoners Gone
item.description: France released its last five German prisoners four years after World War I came to an end.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: U.S. Commandos Capture Six ISIS Officials in Raids in Syria
item.description: The operations were the second time in recent weeks that U.S. forces had killed or captured ISIS terrorists.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: U.S. forces patrolling in northern Syria on Thursday near a rehabilitation center for the children of suspected Islamic State members.

item.title: Trump’s Culpability
item.description: The House Jan. 6 committee placed clear blame on Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: The House committee investigating the Capitol attack met yesterday.

item.title: Zelensky Visits Bakhmut, Aiming To Show Ukraine’s Resolve
item.description: Despite months of Russian bombardments and waves of assaults, the city has remained in Ukrainian control.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A photo made available by the Ukrainian Presidential Press Service shows President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Bakhmut on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The House Jan. 6 committee placed clear blame on Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The action is the culmination of the committee’s intense 18-month investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s effort to overturn the 2020 election.

item.title: Jose Maria Sison, Philippine Communist Party Founder, Dies at 83
item.description: He fielded a force of armed guerrillas, and the organization spread its revolution throughout the country. In exile, he claimed to “lead from abroad.”
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:description: Jose Maria Sison in 2007. A leftist organizer, he founded the Communist Party of the Philippines in 1968 and established its guerrilla force, which grew to 25,000 insurgents.

item.title: Putin Visits Belarus, Stirring New Concern on Future of Ukraine War
item.description: Belarus has resisted being drawn more centrally into the war. But the visit raised worries that a new Russian ground offensive could aim again at Kyiv, near the Belarusian border.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: In a photo distributed by state media, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus in Minsk on Monday.

item.title: US Cybermilitary Force Details Its Support for Ukraine’s Digital Defense
item.description: Russia has struggled to see military gains from its cyberattacks in the world’s first sustained cyberspace battle between two sophisticated militaries.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: A warning message in Ukrainian, Russian and Polish that appeared on the official website of the Ukrainian Foreign Ministry after a massive cyberattack in January.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Jan. 6 Panel Refers Trump for Charges
item.description: Plus: Elon Musk asks Twitter users if he should resign.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:description: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol met on Monday to vote on issuing criminal referrals against Donald Trump.

item.title: Pope Francis to Return 3 Parthenon Marble Fragments to Greece
item.description: The pope will donate the 2,500-year-old pieces held by the Vatican Museums to the archbishop of Athens, a gesture that increases pressure on the British Museum to act over similar items on show in London.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Alex Marshall
item.category: Ministry of Cultural Heritage and Tourism (Italy)
item.media:description: The Greek Ministry of Culture and Sports welcomed Pope Francis’ “generous” decision to return the Parthenon fragments.

item.title: COP15 Biodiversity Talks: Countries Sign On to “30x30” Conservation Plan
item.description: Roughly 190 nations, aiming to halt a dangerous decline in biodiversity, agreed to preserve 30 percent of the planet’s land and seas. The United States is not officially a participant.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:description: The agreement reached in Montreal comes as biodiversity is declining worldwide at rates never seen before in human history.

item.title: Publishing, Under Pressure
item.description: The books business has had a difficult year.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Copies of the book, “Maus,” on the shelf at E.G. Fisher Public Library in Athens, Tennessee.

item.title: The Austere Beauty of Egypt’s Long-Distance Hiking Trails
item.description: Two new routes, managed by Bedouins, will help preserve long-overlooked natural wonders and a vanishing way of life.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Scott
item.media:credit: Sima Diab for The New York Times
item.media:description: An acacia tree in the plains of the Red Sea Mountains, outside Hurghada, Egypt.

item.title: UK High Court Rules on Rwanda Deportation Plan
item.description: The highly criticized effort is meant to deter those crossing the English Channel in small boats, but experts say that it would violate international law.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
item.media:description: Migrants and asylum seekers picked up at sea trying to cross the English Channel arrived in Dungeness, England, this month. More than 40,000 people have made such crossings this year, government figures show.

item.title: Ukraine Selects Its Entry for Eurovision Song Contest
item.description: The electronic music duo Tvorchi won with the song “Heart of Steel,” which the singers said was inspired by the courage of Ukrainian soldiers defending Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: The members of the Ukrainian electronic music duo Tvorchi, Andrew Hutsuliak, left, and Jeffery Kenny, in Kyiv, on Saturday.

item.title: What a Discovery of Old Negatives Revealed About Zaharia Cușnir
item.description: For Zaharia Cusnir, photography was an all-consuming passion. Now, nearly 30 years after he died in obscurity, the Moldovan’s fame is rising.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Photographs by Zaharia Cusnir outside his old home in Rosietici, Moldova. He depicted people as they wanted to be seen, as individuals brimming with character.

item.title: Seeking Heat, and Companionship, in a Hard Scotland Winter
item.description: In a Glasgow neighborhood, the cost-of-living crisis is exacerbating energy problems and financial worries, and vital community hubs are struggling to stay afloat.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Lochs, a shopping center that has fallen into disrepair, provides a snapshot of the deterioration in lower-income communities like Easterhouse, in Glasgow.

item.title: Royal Thai Navy Scrambles to Rescue 31 After Its Ship Sinks
item.description: Officials said the HTMS Sukhothai took on water, lost power and eventually sank in the Gulf of Thailand overnight.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Royal Thai Navy, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The HTMS Sukhothai leaning on its side off the coast of Prachuap Khiri Khan Province, Thailand, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A World Cup final for the ages.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Lionel Messi, kissing the World Cup trophy, scored two of Argentina’s three goals.

item.title: Putin’s visit signals pressure is mounting on Belarus’s leader to expand support for Russia’s war.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: President Alexander Lukashenko of Belarus, left, speaking with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the airport in Minsk, Belarus, on Monday.

item.title: 5 Killed in Shooting at Canadian Condo Building, Police Say
item.description: The 73-year-old gunman, who was fatally shot by the police at a high-rise building in Vaughan, Ontario, had been in a long-running feud with the condo board.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police at the scene of the mass shooting in Vaughan, Ontario, on Monday.

item.title: Drone Attacks Target Kyiv and Two Other Ukrainian Regions
item.description: Ukraine said that it had shot down 20 of 35 drones that Russia had launched, though those that evaded air defenses had hit power plants, electrical systems and other civilian targets.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A drone attack at a power plant in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: In Heart of Peru’s Protest, a Pause to Mourn the Dead
item.description: Confrontations between protesters and the Peruvian authorities have left at least 25 dead and hundreds injured. Nowhere may tensions be higher than in the highland city of Ayacucho.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Victor Moriyama
item.media:description: The funeral procession for Clemer Fabricio Rojas and Christopher Michael Ramos on Saturday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Argentina Triumphs
item.description: Plus: A Times analysis of how Russia bungled the invasion.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Lionel Messi of Argentina lifted the FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 Winner’s Trophy after winning final match against France in Lusail City, Qatar, on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine Says Russia May Be Planning Winter Offensive
item.description: An adviser to President Volodymyr Zelensky urged Western allies to take seriously the threat of a new Russian onslaught, which could include mass infantry attacks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in Bakhmut on Sunday.

item.title: UK Moves to Eliminate Some Liquid and Laptop Airport Security Rules
item.description: New technology could clear a path for relaxed security checks at airports by June 2024.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Passengers over the summer at Heathrow Airport outside London. New technology will, its backers say, save time and improve security.

item.title: What Russia Got Wrong
item.description: A cascade of military failures started with Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Counting Russia’s War Dead in Ukraine
item.description: Amid doubts about Moscow’s true war losses, Russian data journalists and volunteers use news articles, tombstone photographs and other open-source information to tally the Russian toll from the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: The funeral of the Russian serviceman Nikita Avrov, 20, in Luga, Russia, in March. Some researchers working to compile a list of Russians who died in the war in Ukraine visit cemeteries to check tombstones.

item.title: Local News Outlet in New York Faces New Hurdle: A Declined Visa
item.description: Phil O’Brien, a Briton who has run a Manhattan publication for several years, had his visa denied because immigration officials deemed his struggling business “marginal.”
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Suzie Howell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Phil O’Brien, publisher of W42ST, a Hell’s Kitchen local news site, was denied a visa renewal to the United States.

item.title: How Can Tainted Spinach Cause Hallucinations?
item.description: A food recall from Australia sheds light on an unusual aspect of brain chemistry.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Baby spinach in a California field. The healthful green was recently the subject of an urgent recall in Australia, where some other plant is thought to have ended up packaged with it.

item.title: South Korea Accuses the North of Launching Missiles. The North Says It Was a Satellite Test.
item.description: The North has made similar claims before when it was in fact preparing for ICBM launches.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: News coverage in Seoul of North Korea’s missile launch on Sunday.

item.title: India’s Urdu Poetry Festival Draws Stadium Crowds
item.description: That 300,000 people celebrated Urdu verse during a three-day festival was testament to the peculiar reality of the language in India.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: The inaugural day of the Urdu poetry festival Jashn-e-Rekhta in New Delhi this month.

item.title: Military Spending Surges, Creating New Boom for Arms Makers
item.description: The combination of the war in Ukraine and concern about longer-term threats from Russia and China is driving a bipartisan push to increase U.S. capacity to produce weapons.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Taraneh Alidoosti, Iranian Actress, Arrested After Voicing Support for Protests
item.description: The actress, Taraneh Alidoosti, had urged people to speak out after the execution of a man involved in nationwide demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Taraneh Alidoosti in May at the International Film Festival in Cannes, France.

item.title: Behind Argentina’s World Cup Magic, an Army of Witches
item.description: France might have its star Kylian Mbappé, but Argentina has hundreds of “brujas” casting spells to protect Lionel Messi and the rest of its national squad.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Lankes
item.media:credit: Anita Pouchard Serra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Magalí Martínez, a self-proclaimed witch, is one of hundreds who has used magic to try to help Argentina’s soccer team.

item.title: Putin Visits Ukraine War Headquarters
item.description: The meetings with his top brass seemed to signal a shift from his largely hands-off public posture to one conveying a more active role in war planning.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: In a photo distributed by Russian media, President Vladimir V. Putin made a surprise visit to Ukraine command headquarters to meet with his top officers for “short- and mid-term” planning of the war.

item.title: Ukrainians Focus on Resilience a Day After Major Russian Strikes
item.description: The mayor of Kyiv said that water was back on and that the city’s subway service had resumed. President Volodymyr Zelensky urged businesses to help set up more “invincibility centers” for the public.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Ukrainian State Emergency Service firefighters clearing rubble from a building that was destroyed by a Russian attack in Kryvyi Rih on Friday.

item.title: The Best of 2022
item.description: It’s best-of season. Let’s dig in.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Revisiting an Anti-Immigrant Quebec Town Uncovers a Plot Twist
item.description: Norimitsu Onishi, a New York Times reporter, traveled to Hérouxville, Quebec, to learn what had happened in the 15 years since the town passed its xenophobic immigration code.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town hall in Hérouxville, Quebec.

item.title: World Cup Final Caps a Complex Saga Between Messi and Argentina
item.description: Lionel Messi left Argentina when he was 13 and has had a complicated relationship with the nation since. But this World Cup has changed things.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Sebastián López Brach
item.media:description: Thousands of fans in the city of Rosario, where Lionel Messi was born, celebrated Argentina’s win on Tuesday.

item.title: How the Xenophobic Town of Hérouxville, Quebec, Fell in Love With Immigrants
item.description: “We now want as many immigrants as possible,” said Bernard Thompson, the mayor of Hérouxville, Quebec, a onetime supporter of the town’s anti-immigrant code.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city center of Hérouxville is quiet and mostly residential, with few vacant properties. Affordable housing is a primary concern for regional officials hoping to stimulate immigration to the area.

item.title: When Did the Anthropocene Start? Scientists Closer to Saying When.
item.description: A panel of experts has spent more than a decade deliberating on how, and whether, to mark a momentous new epoch in geologic time: our own.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

item.title: Eight Takeaways From The Times’s Investigation Into Putin’s War in Ukraine
item.description: Secret Russian battle plans, intercepts, and interviews with Russian soldiers and Kremlin confidants revealed new details of how Vladimir Putin botched his invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remnants of a Russian convoy in Bucha, Ukraine.

item.title: Leo Varadkar, Ireland’s Returning Leader, Has Lots to Prove
item.description: In Leo Varadkar’s first stint as prime minister, he embodied for many his country’s move into modernity. But after several missteps, he now takes up the role for a second time, with the glow of optimism dimmed.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Leo Varadkar in October in Dublin. He was one of Europe’s youngest heads of government at the start of his first term and was his country’s first openly gay prime minister, or taoiseach.

item.title: Tunisia Heads for First Elections Since Presidential Power Grab
item.description: Voters will choose a new Parliament, but under revised rules that vastly dilute the influence of political parties that many blame for sabotaging the North African nation’s 10-year experiment with democracy.
item.dc:creator: Ahmed Ellali and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: A billboard in the Tunisian capital, Tunis, on Thursday encourages people to vote in Parliamentary elections on Saturday.
